citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The licensee is not following written instructions from the Attending Veterinarian (AV). The written program of veterinary
care for dogs states that dogs shall be treated each month for external parasites (fleas and ticks). The licensee stated that
he does not treat the dogs every month for fleas and ticks, but added that he believes the oral dewormer he uses monthly
to treat for internal parasites would also treat fleas and ticks. The AV was contacted and confirmed that the dogs should
get a treatment each month for fleas and ticks, and that the oral dewormer currently used does not treat fleas and ticks.
Additionally, the amount of oral dewormer given to the dogs is incorrect. the AV calculated amount of oral dewormer to
give the dogs to prevent Heartworm and wrote the amounts each dog needs on the program of veterinary care. Medical
records and discussion with the licensee showed that the dogs were getting less than the amount prescribed by the AV.
One of the dogs recently tested positive for Heartworm.
The written program of veterinary care contains instructions from the AV about medical and husbandry practices that are
important to maintain animal health. Failing to follow the AV's instructions may result in negative impacts on animal health
such as infestation with internal or external parasites or administration of the wrong amount of medication(s). Correct by
July 1, 2023 by following the instructions in the written program of veterinary care, and contacting the AV regarding any
questions or clarifications that are necessary to fully follow the written plan.

Medical records were incomplete for one adult border collie dog ("Bandit"). The licensee stated he was giving the dog
antibiotics daily, as prescribed by the Attending Veterinarian. However, the medical record did not contain any daily
entries showing that the antibiotics were being given to the animal. The medical record also lacked a description of the
dog's medical problem that was being treated. Accurate and complete medical records are required for dogs in order to
keep track of when problems arise, and when medications are given. Correct by by maintaining medical records for dogs
which include all of the required elements listed in 3.13.

The outdoor area of a sheltered housing facility containing two adult white-throated capuchin monkeys is not completely
enclosed by a perimeter fence. The outdoor area of the enclosure has chain link walls and roof, beyond which there is
some additional fencing of various heights. However, there is not one continuous 6 feet tall perimeter fence around the
outside area of the monkey enclosure. A perimeter fence is essential for preventing contact between exotic animals and
unauthorized people or animals. A perimeter fence also acts as a secondary containment system in the event an animal
escapes from its primary enclosure. Correct by installing a perimeter fence that is at least 6 feet tall around the outdoor
area of the primate enclosure, or by obtaining approval from the Administrator for alternative measures.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the owner.
